title: 107_hr119
content: The "Commission on Elections Procedures Act" establishes a Commission to study and make recommendations on standardized voting procedures for Federal, State, and local elections. The Commission's purpose is to improve electoral processes through the implementation of standardized technology. The Commission on Elections Procedures Act establishes a 10-member Commission appointed by various officials, with members required to have expertise in election laws, the Constitution, and US history. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, starting within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Elections Procedures Act establishes a 10-member Commission appointed by various officials with expertise in election laws, the Constitution, and US history. Appointments are for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of its members. The members select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson, and a majority of the Commission constitutes a quorum for business transactions. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining government electoral processes and making recommendations. They will address voting procedures, legislation affecting voting, and the implementation of standardized voting procedures. A final report is due within 12 months of the Commission's initial meeting. The Commission will submit a final report to the President, Congress, and Federal Election Commission with an analysis and recommendations on electoral processes. Any member can include additional findings and recommendations in the report. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and request administrative support services as needed to fulfill the requirements of the Act. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request, on a reimbursable basis, to help carry out its duties under this Act. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on their status as federal government officers or employees. Non-government members will receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members will serve without additional compensation. All members will be reimbursed for travel expenses at authorized rates. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint and terminate staff, request the detail of Federal employees, and accept temporary services. The employment of an executive director is subject to the Commission's approval. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. $2,000,000 is authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act.
